title: Incident Response
description: Preparing for, detecting, and responding to security incidents

questions.question: Do you have an incident response plan?
questions.context: A documented plan for handling security incidents including roles, responsibilities, and procedures.
questions.examples: Incident response plan, IR procedures, contact lists, escalation procedures
questions.followUp: Show me your IR plan. When was it last updated? Who's on the response team?
questions.discussion: An incident response plan ensures consistent, effective response to security incidents. It defines roles, responsibilities, and procedures.
assessmentObjectives: IR plan exists and is documented

questions.question: Do you track and report incidents?
questions.context: Incidents need to be documented, tracked through resolution, and reported as required.
questions.examples: Incident tickets, tracking system, incident database, reporting procedures
questions.followUp: How do you track incidents? What gets reported and to whom? Show me recent examples.
questions.discussion: Incident tracking ensures no incidents are forgotten, patterns are identified, and required reporting occurs.

questions.question: Do you test your incident response capability?
questions.context: IR plans need regular testing through exercises, simulations, or tabletops.
questions.examples: Tabletop exercises, IR drills, simulated incidents, red team exercises
questions.followUp: When was the last IR test? What type? What did you learn? Any improvements made?
questions.discussion: Testing validates the incident response plan works and team members know their roles. Tests identify gaps and improvements.

questions.question: Do you provide incident response training?
questions.context: Response team members need training on their roles and the IR procedures.
questions.examples: IR team training, role-specific training, annual refreshers, new member training
questions.followUp: What IR training is provided? Who gets it? How often? Is it role-specific?
questions.discussion: Training ensures incident response team members can effectively perform their duties during an actual incident.

questions.question: Do you have incident detection and analysis capabilities?
questions.context: You need to detect incidents quickly and analyze them to understand impact and response.
questions.examples: IDS/IPS, SIEM, log analysis, anomaly detection, forensic tools
questions.followUp: How do you detect incidents? What analysis tools do you have? Who does analysis?
questions.discussion: Detection and analysis capabilities enable organizations to identify incidents quickly and understand their scope and impact.

questions.question: Do you contain, eradicate, and recover from incidents?
questions.context: Incidents need to be contained to prevent spread, threats removed, and systems recovered.
questions.examples: Isolation procedures, malware removal, system restoration, backup recovery
questions.followUp: How do you contain incidents? What's the eradication process? How do you recover?
questions.discussion: Containment limits damage, eradication removes the threat, and recovery restores normal operations while preventing reinfection.

questions.question: Do you perform post-incident reviews?
questions.context: After incidents, review what happened, what worked, what didn't, and how to improve.
questions.examples: Post-incident reports, lessons learned meetings, root cause analysis, improvement plans
questions.followUp: Do you review all incidents? What's documented? How are improvements tracked?
questions.discussion: Post-incident activities improve security posture by identifying root causes, evaluating response effectiveness, and implementing improvements.
